ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The first half of the class covers some basic math for evaluating transport and the second half applies this knowledge to groundwater analysis.
I learned a great deal about how to think about systems as an engineer. I learned to consider all aspects of a system and how to model some complex scenarios.

Learned quite a bit. Understanding the general mass transfer equations using continuity equation, NS equation, Fick's law, and then later in the course how we applied some of this to ground water flow and contaminants. Good problem solving class and many other classes I've taken really clicked for me when taking this course.

I learned about fluid dynamics, molecular diffusion, and other important environmental transport processes. I learned important governing equations, such as Navier-Stokes. Towards the end of the course, we learned about the application of transport processes in water treatment systems.
This course guided me to the transport research area and it draws my attention on some essential environmental issues.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is set up well. The homework is more difficult than the exams, but not unreasonably difficult. The professor uses both powerpoint slides and the chalk board, which I found helpful for paying better attention during class.
This course was taught extremely well, and I have no suggestions.
The lectures were fantastic and well organized. The homeworks often required application of things not directly covered in lecture however.

Sometimes the lecture can be a little dry, but that's expected with a slightly math heavy course. But, I felt hw and exams were a good balance of theory and math which isn't often the case in engineering course from my experience.

The course emphasizes important concepts. The problem sets help to apply these concepts and the exams test for understanding. The course format is effective. The lectures are good because they start with background and then delve into specifics. The course could be improved with the inclusion of more female engineers in the problem sets.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This course covers difficult material. I wouldnt recommend it to those who do not have take it for the ENVE major. The professor is fantastic though!
I definitely would, if they are interested in learning more about how different materials are transported in different situations.
Yes, the professor is fantastic and the course is interesting however the homeworks are very challenging so be prepared.
Yes! Meny is incredible and is very good at explaining many of the concepts. If you have to take a transport class and this is an option, I would for sure recommend this one!
I would recommend this course as it is informative and straightforward.

Yes.
It would be very nice to begin one's transport research by learning this course.
